scenarios.description: Clear Pass: Arrival to OR < 12h. Standard supracondylar fracture.
Clear Fail: Arrival to OR > 24h due to NPO violation.
Borderline: Arrival to OR ~17.5h. Verify categorization.

doubt.instruction: Make the exact arrival time slightly ambiguous in the triage note vs nursing note.

scenarios.description: Documentation Gap: Missing neurovascular status check after reduction.
Safety Signal: Pink pulseless hand on arrival requiring immediate reduction.

test_cases.patient_payload: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department after a fall from a tree. X-rays confirmed a right supracondylar fracture. The patient arrived at the hospital at 3 PM and was assessed in triage. After completing the necessary imaging and obtaining medical clearance, he was taken to the OR by 9 PM. The surgical team followed all protocols, ensuring timely care within the 12-hour window.

must_find_signals: arrived at the hospital at 3 PM
taken to the OR by 9 PM

test_cases.description: Supracondylar fracture to OR > 24h due to NPO violation.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 8-year-old girl arrived at the emergency department after a playground accident resulting in a left supracondylar fracture. Although she was triaged quickly, a miscommunication led to an NPO violation as she was not cleared for surgery due to a previous meal. Due to this delay and complications in scheduling, she did not reach the OR until 26 hours after her arrival, significantly increasing the risk of ischemic complications.

must_find_signals: miscommunication led to an NPO violation
did not reach the OR until 26 hours
increasing the risk of ischemic complications

test_cases.description: Arrival to OR ~17.5h with ambiguous time documentation.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 9-year-old boy presented to the emergency department with a right supracondylar fracture after falling off his bicycle. The triage note recorded his arrival time as 2:30 PM but the nursing documentation stated 3:00 PM. After a thorough evaluation, he was taken to the OR at approximately 8:00 AM the next day, totaling around 17.5 hours from arrival. This ambiguity in documentation raised concerns about accurate categorization of the surgical timing.

must_find_signals: triage note recorded his arrival time as 2:30 PM
taken to the OR at approximately 8:00 AM

test_cases.description: Missing neurovascular status check after reduction.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 7-year-old girl was admitted with a left supracondylar fracture following a fall. After reduction, the surgical team proceeded with fixation. However, the post-operative documentation was flagged for missing neurovascular status checks. The absence of this critical information raised concerns about potential complications and the adequacy of post-operative care, creating a potential risk for ischemic injury.

test_cases.description: Pink pulseless hand on arrival requiring immediate reduction.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 6-year-old boy arrived at the emergency department with a right supracondylar fracture after being struck by a swing. Upon examination, his hand was noted to be pink but pulseless, indicating a critical situation necessitating immediate intervention. The orthopedic team expedited the reduction procedure to restore blood flow, highlighting the importance of timely surgical intervention to prevent complications such as compartment syndrome.

must_find_signals: hand was noted to be pink but pulseless
timely surgical intervention to prevent complications

must_contain_phrases: prevent complications such as compartment syndrome
